name: Random Forests and aggregation methods
tagline: This projects aggregates a Bagging, Random Forest and MLP classifier for data competition
body:
## Random Forests and aggregation methods
This post focuses on aggregation methods. Random Forest and Bootstrap Aggregation are by themselves instances of aggregation methods. In line of a data competition, we have team members make a classifier each and aggregate them to a final submission.

## Data
The data is part of a class competition hosted by professor Alexandre Thiery for the Data mining course at NUS. The data consists of 20.000 labeled samples for training and 20.000 unlabeled samples for evaluation. Targets are seven classes. The training data is split in __train_data.csv__, __test_data.csv__ and __assembling_data.csv__ for our training purposes.

## Ensemble
The main script is __ensemble.py__, which takes in the distribution over the classes for each sample in both the __assembling_data.csv__ and the final test data. 
The individual classifiers with the accuracies for the __assembling_data.csv__
  *  Naive Bayes classfier: 77%
  *  Random Forest (with 22 covariates taken for each split): 95.8%
  *  Bagging: 96.4% 
  *  Neural Network (1 hidden layer, 115 neurons): 96.4%  
  *  Multi-class one-vs-one LASSO: 92.8%
  *  Multi-class one-vs-one RIDGE: $93.5 \%$

Code for the individual classifiers in __baggin_main.m__, __random_forest_main.r__ (author: Mareva Brixy) and __MLP_1_hidden.py__. 

## Aggregation
For the aggregation, we take a naive weighted average. The weights are the accuracies as obtained on the __assembling_data.csv__. With some selection, we obtain 96.6% accuracy by combining the Random Forest, Bagging and Neural network. Already, this naive weighted average as an ensemble outperforms the individual accuracies.

## Output
A typical output of the script would be like this
![example_output](https://github.com/RobRomijnders/trees_ensemble/blob/master/output_example.png?raw=true)
Per classifier, you will get the confusion matrix, the accuracy on the labeled data and the average confidence per misclassified sample. Moreover, you will get the ensemble accuracy and metrics for the unlabeled dataset.

As always, I am curious to any comments and questions. Reach me at romijndersrob@gmail.com
